page.title: 04Milking, N.Alcester
page.content: Most of the area's 10 farms have dairy herds. This is how it is done on one of them. A young cow only starts to give milk after her first calf is born, then the calf is taken from its mother and fed by the farmer. Cows are milked twice a day. They walk one by one into the milking parlour, and stand facing outwards in a herring bone pattern. During milking, food is automatically put into their troughs, the udders and teats are washed, then the metal cups of the machine are put on. The milk is sucked by vacuum into glass jars, through pipes, to a large cooled tank. Each cow gives about 4 gallons a day and a tanker takes the milk to the dairy. It is tested every day to make sure it is safe for people to drink. Milk from a cow given medicine cannot be used.
